docTitle.titlePart:
Transformation of cacao butter crystals and
blooming

front.div:
Overview
The cacao butter is a polymorphic crystal and
determines the properties of the chocolate.
High quality chocolate melts at body
temperature has a firm grip, a shiny surface
and a sound snap when breaking. The crystal
of type β(V) meets best those desired
properties and thus chocolate makers try to
optimize its ratio in their recipes. Under non
ideal storage conditions, especially at too high
temperatures, the cacao butter may undergo a
β(V)→ β(VI) phase transition which causes the
white-greyish layer on the surface, the fat
bloom. Surfaces from the fresh chocolate bar
and a chocolate bar that suffered froom
blooming were performed with GISAXS
experiments. Additionally transmission SAXS
experiments have been made as reference.

Experimental
The samples used for the experiment were fine
slices of dark chocolate from Lindt. One batch
has developed fat blooming after the seal of
the packaging box has been broken and left for
a couple of days under sunlight and heat
exposure on the desk. The blooming has been
identified as fat bloom in contrast to sugar
bloom. A piece of a fat bloom affected
chocolate slice and another piece from a slice
of a fresh package with good looking chocolate
slices were used for the experiments. X-ray
experiments have been performed with a
Hecus S3-MicroPix camera (Hecus X-ray
Systems, Graz, Austria). The wavelength used
was λ=1.54 Å. The vertical collimator slit
setting chosen was 200 µm. The detector used
was a Pilatus2D detector from Dectris with a
pixel size of 172 µm ×172 µm. The measured
q-range was till 0.6 Å
-1 without covering the
direct beam. For the GISAXS experiments the
samples were mounted on the GISAXS sample
holder and for the SAXS transmission control
experiments the samples slices were placed
vertically in the solid sample holder.
